Award.AwardTitle: MATH: EAGER:Mathematical Problem Solving Item Development Project

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Access to STEM careers relies heavily on student success in their foundational mathematics courses. Little is understood about the mathematical problem solving capacity students must develop in order to leverage mathematical knowledge from prior courses in learning mathematics central to their field of study. The Mathematical Problem Solving Item (MPSI) Development Project will create a pool of validated problems and associated assessment items that indicate a student's mathematical problem solving (MPS) in five key areas identified in the research literature: (a) sense-making/ orienting, (b) representing/ connecting, (c) challenge/ difficulty, (d) reviewing, and (e) defending/ justifying. To this end, the project will: (1) develop and refine items that indicate levels of MPS in the five areas stated above with students in college algebra and calculus. To this end, the project will pilot and refine items with approximately 1600 college algebra students and 1400 calculus student; (2) validate items by convening a panel of experts in MPS; and (3) use a pre- and post-assessment design to examine the extent to which the MPSI items capture the elements of MPS.

In contrast to labor- and time-intensive measures of students' MPS capacity that involve task-based interviews and review of student work using detailed scoring rubrics, the MPSI item design will provide items that use a Likert-type scale and can be machine scored. The project will investigate the extent to which the items capture the impact of curricula in college algebra and calculus on MPS as well as the extent to which success in these mathematics courses can be inferred from student MPS profiles derived from performance on MPSI project items. The MPSI project will provide an important and efficient tool that separates skills, procedural knowledge, and conceptual knowledge gained in a course from the MPS levels needed to leverage this mathematical knowledge in future courses and to persist in STEM fields.

ProgramReference.Text: Math Success in First 2 Years of College

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcome of this project is a pool of 8 mathematical problems and 40 associated Likert items that can be used to assess mathematical problem solving (MPS) in five key MPS domains linked to the research literature. Problems and items are designed for entry-level undergraduate students (e.g., students in courses such as College Algebra and Calculus). The development of the mathematics problems and the associated Likert items aims eventually to enable the creation of an assessment of MPS in entry-level college courses. We anticipate that students would individually complete 5 problems and 25 associated Likert items in a one-hour assessment of MPS. Each Likert item is linked to the student’s use of one of the MPS domains: sense-making, representing/ connecting, reviewing, justifying, and challenge. Likert items can be machine-scored and, hence, offer an efficient and affordable way to assess MPS, which historically has been assessed through lengthy analyses of written student work or think-aloud interviews.

Assessments developed from the problems and associated items created by this project could be used in several research settings. For example, the items could provide information about MPS skills needed for student success in courses such as college algebra or calculus. Such a tool for research does not currently exist, and our approach has the potential to transform the way in which mathematics education researchers investigate MPS. Items could also be used by practitioners and course instructors to provide information on students’ levels of MPS in the five domains. For example, instructors could assess student readiness for university-level mathematics, gain information regarding their students’ MPS practices, or provide information motivating course improvement and redesign. Such information has the potential to positively affect thousands of students struggling in entry-level undergraduate mathematics courses, many of whom come from historically underserved groups.
